item.title: Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy Will Retire
item.media:description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy sent a letter to President Trump announcing his retirement from the Supreme Court.
item.description: The announcement gives President Trump the opportunity to create a solid five-member conservative majority and fundamentally change the direction of the court.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: News Analysis: In Influence if Not in Title, This Has Been the Kennedy Court
item.media:description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy in 2015. He has served on the Supreme Court for more than 30 years.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy occupied a place at the court’s ideological center for his entire tenure, with his vote often the crucial one in closely divided cases.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: News Analysis: Anthony Kennedy’s Exit May Echo for Generations
item.media:description: By replacing the retiring Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, right, President Trump has a chance to cement his legacy by adding another solidly conservative justice to the Supreme Court alongside his first choice, Neil M. Gorsuch, center.
item.description: Despite President Trump’s rocky tenure, his opportunity to reshape the Supreme Court may allow him to go down in history as an unusually influential president.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: McConnell Promises Fall Vote to Confirm Next Supreme Court Justice
item.media:description: Another Trump-appointed justice would be a crowning judicial triumph for Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, who led the blockade against President Barack Obama’s nominee in 2016.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy’s retirement throws the volatile issue of a Supreme Court confirmation to the Senate, and Democrats have little power to stop it.
item.dc:creator: CARL HULSE

item.title: The Front-Runners and Full List of Potential Supreme Court Nominees
item.media:description: President Trump spoke from the Oval Office on Wednesday.
item.description: The president has said he intends to choose his next Supreme Court nominee from a list he began compiling during the 2016 campaign.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Europe Edition: Supreme Court, Migration, Poland: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN and MATTHEW SEDACCA

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Delivers a Sharp Blow to Labor Unions
item.media:description: Mark Janus, center, who sued his public sector union, outside the Supreme Court today with Gov. Bruce Rauner of Illinois.
item.description: The court ruled that government workers cannot be required to pay for collective bargaining, which could cost public unions tens of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees

item.title: News Analysis: Labor Unions Will Be Smaller After Supreme Court Decision, but Maybe Not Weaker
item.media:description: A crowd listening to Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, at a rally in support of unionized workers outside a Boston firehouse in February. The rally was held to coincide with the Supreme Court arguments in a challenge to public-sector unions.
item.description: The ruling could cost public-sector unions more than a million members. But the ones who stay could make labor more powerful.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees

item.title: What the Janus Decision Means for Teacher Unions
item.media:description: Arizona teachers protested in April in a statewide walkout, one of several this year. The walkout movement offered a glimmer of hope for teachers’ unions, which lost the right to collect agency fees.
item.description: Teachers’ unions could lose up to a third of their members and funding as a result of the Supreme Court ruling, labor experts say.
item.dc:creator: DANA GOLDSTEIN and ERICA L. GREEN

item.title: With One Win, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Emerges as a Political Star
item.media:description: If Ms. Ocasio-Cortez defeats her Republican opponent in November, she, at 28, would be the youngest woman ever elected to Congress.
item.media:credit: Annie Tritt for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Ocasio-Cortez has been a waitress, a community activist and a campaign organizer for Bernie Sanders. Now she is a political rock star.
item.dc:creator: ANDY NEWMAN, VIVIAN WANG and LUIS FERRÉ-SADURNÍ

item.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez: I’m ‘Unapologetic About What I Believe’
item.description: The Bronx native spoke about her campaign’s mission a day after she shook up the Democratic Party with her defeat of Representative Joseph Crowley.

item.title: An Upset in the Making: Why Joe Crowley Never Saw Defeat Coming
item.media:description: Representative Joseph Crowley, at a news conference in Washington last week, had not faced a Democratic primary since his congressional district was redrawn to include a section of the Bronx.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: No one factor caused Mr. Crowley’s loss. Demographics, generational change and an aggressive grass-roots campaign by his opponent all were factors.
item.dc:creator: SHANE GOLDMACHER

item.title: In Volgograd, It’s Stalin Who Lurks on the Sideline
item.media:description: Joseph Stalin's bust at a museum commemorating the Battle of Stalingrad. Stalin is inescapable in Volgograd.
item.description: The World Cup will depart Volgograd on Thursday after a final first-round game in this city along the Volga River. What will remain are all the echoes of the past.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL and MAXIM BABENKO

item.title: Germany Crashes Out of World Cup With a Loss to South Korea
item.media:description: Thomas Müller of Germany was dejected as Germany lost to South Korea on Wednesday.
item.description: South Korea stunned Germany with a 2-0 victory on Wednesday, knocking the defending champion out of the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

item.title: ‘Never Do This to a Woman’: Men Harass 2 Sports Reporters at the World Cup
item.media:description: Julieth González Therán, who works for the Spanish language division of the German broadcaster Deutsche Welle, was approached by a man this month while broadcasting live from Moscow.
item.description: Two widely viewed videos show one reporter being kissed and grabbed, and another reporter dodging a man’s advances.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Trump and Putin Will Hold Summit Meeting, Officials Say
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, with John R. Bolton, President Trump’s national security adviser, on Wednesday at the Kremlin.
item.description: The gathering has worried some European allies, who fear it could overshadow a NATO summit meeting and President Trump’s visit to Britain in mid-July.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: As Summit Nears, NATO Allies Have One Main Worry: Trump
item.media:description: After his angry performance with fellow Group of 7 leaders, allies fear that President Trump will deliver a noisy, divisive NATO summit meeting next month.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: After the fiasco of the Group of 7 meeting, where the president publicly criticized allies, NATO countries dread a similar performance, helping Russia.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Eastern Europe, U.S. Military Girds Against Russian Might and Manipulation
item.media:description: To practice their ability to move quickly in a crisis and sustain themselves along the way, American troops recently drove 950 vehicles about 840 miles from their base in Vilseck, Germany, to a training range in southern Lithuania — roughly the distance from New York to Atlanta.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: American soldiers and allies, on a military exercise in Poland and Lithuania, are ramping up to thwart Russian cyberattacks and information warfare.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: BULLETIN BOARD: Our International Report Becomes a Bit More Modern
item.media:description: Azam Ahmed, a New York Times correspondent, reporting from Mexico. Our international desk wants to give readers a sense of being there on the ground with our correspondents.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Journals have long been a way for The Times’s foreign correspondents to bring readers with them as they explore a distant land. But they have needed a reboot, our international editor writes.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SLACKMAN

item.title: With Kennedy Gone, Justice Must Be Won at the Ballot Box
item.media:description: Judge Neil Gorsuch and Justice Anthony Kennedy during the swearing-in ceremony of Judge Gorsuch to the Supreme Court on April 10, 2017.
item.description: Strengthening America’s other democratic institutions has never been more important.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: We’re About to Find Out How Bad It Will Get Without Justice Kennedy
item.media:description: Anthony Kennedy, who announced his retirement on Wednesday after 30 years on the Supreme Court.
item.description: He provided a crucial fifth vote to the court’s conservative wing, but he sometimes voted against it, especially on abortion.
item.dc:creator: EMILY BAZELON

item.title: Editorial: After Janus, Unions Must Save Themselves
item.description: The Supreme Court’s decision imperils public-sector unions. Whether they survive will be up to them.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Trump Remakes America
item.media:description: A Trump supporter outside the Supreme Court on Tuesday.
item.description: With Justice Anthony Kennedy retiring, Trump gets his legacy.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES M. BLOW
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Why Do We Value Country Folk More Than City People?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Jeffrey Henson Scales; photographs by Paul D. Van Hoy II/Age Fotostock and Toshi Sasaki, via Photolibrary, via Getty Images
item.description: Our politics are cracking up over the density divide.
item.dc:creator: WILL WILKINSON

item.title: Janus Decision Reins in Unions’ Political Power
item.media:description: Construction workers and union members at a rally in New York's Columbus Circle, in May.
item.description: Public employee unions have too much influence in some states. The Supreme Court’s ruling will take them down a peg.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL DISALVO

item.title: How the Supreme Court Replaced One Injustice With Another
item.media:description: Japanese-Americans arriving at the Manzanar internment camp — one of 10 such camps established during World War II — in Owens Valley, Calif., in 1942.
item.media:credit: Eliot Elisofon/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.description: My father, Fred Korematsu, would have been upset that the court overturned his case only to uphold President Trump’s travel ban.
item.dc:creator: KAREN KOREMATSU
item.category: Korematsu v United States (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: Donald Trump’s Worst Nightmare
item.description: “Sometimes you’re not in the mood to shake hands with everybody.”

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: How, Exactly, Does This Travel Ban Keep Us Safe, Mr. President?
item.media:description: Two bombs exploded near the Boston Marathon finish line on April 15, 2013.
item.media:credit: Ben Thorndike/Ben Thorndike, via Associated Press
item.description: The illusion of security, purchased at an exorbitant cost to America’s moral reputation.
item.dc:creator: BRET STEPHENS

item.title: Can Raya Install a Wondrous Utopia While Also Helping Celebrities Hook Up?
item.media:description: An app man in his native environment.
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.description: The founder of an exclusive dating app is stepping forward for the first time. His next project? Making our society more ideal.
item.dc:creator: KEVIN ROOSE

item.title: Benicio Del Toro, Hollywood’s Instant Antihero, Goes the Distance
item.media:description: If it's a choice between breaking a stereotype or taking a good part, he'll take the part, adding, “I have my own life — I can make sure to break the stereotype there.”
item.media:credit: Jody Rogac for The New York Times
item.description: The economical actor has burned brightly in all his films, from “The Usual Suspects” to “The Last Jedi.” Now, with an action franchise and a mini-series, he’s learning to linger.
item.dc:creator: REGGIE UGWU

item.title: Books of The Times: Going for Broke, the Middle Class Goes Broke
item.description: “Squeezed: Why Our Families Can’t Afford America,” by Alissa Quart, is a timely book about the increasing number of people who feel profound economic vulnerability.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER SZALAI
item.category: Squeezed: Why Our Families Cant Afford America (Book)

item.title: Trump, at Rally, Vows to Carry On Anthony Kennedy’s Legacy With Court Pick
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday at a political rally in Fargo, N.D., where he said he wanted to pick a Supreme Court nominee who could spend at least 40 years on the bench.
item.description: At a rally in North Dakota, the president celebrated an indisputable political trophy as he tries to drum up support for Republicans before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Netherlands Approves Partial Ban on Face Coverings
item.media:description: A woman wearing a burqa walked past the Palace of Justice in The Hague in 2014. The Dutch parliament’s Upper House approved on Tuesday a partial ban on face coverings in some public areas, a spokesman said.
item.description: The law, approved by the Dutch parliament’s Upper House on Tuesday, also bans ski masks and helmets, but it would directly affect some Muslim women.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER and LIAM STACK

item.title: Immigration Lawyer Broke Her Foot When ICE Officer Pushed Her, She Says
item.media:description: Andrea Martinez, a Kansas City immigration lawyer, said she fractured her foot after being pushed to the ground by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer.
item.description: The lawyer said she was trying to follow her client, an undocumented 3-year-old boy, into an agency building in Kansas City, Mo., to reunite him with his mother before they were deported.
item.dc:creator: MIHIR ZAVERI

item.title: Hills Ablaze Above Manchester as U.K. Wildfire Rages for 4th Day
item.media:description: Wildfire swept across the moors near Manchester, England, on Tuesday.
item.description: Firefighters sought military help to fight a blaze across seven miles of countryside on the edge of one of England’s most populous urban areas.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: A Seismic Change in Predicting How Earthquakes Will Shake Tall Buildings
item.media:description: Researchers on Wednesday reported that decades of calculations used to construct tall buildings in earthquake-prone areas like Los Angeles significantly underestimated the shaking expected to occur.
item.media:credit: Monica Almeida forThe New York Times
item.description: Seismologists say shaking from earthquakes in some West Coast cities will be much stronger than previously thought.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: As Cameroon English Speakers Fight to Break Away, Violence Mounts
item.media:description: A market in Bamenda, Cameroon, last November after a homemade bomb exploded overnight.
item.description: Some of the Central African country’s Anglophones want to found a country called Ambazonia. The French-speaking government is deeply opposed.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: House Rejects Immigration Overhaul Despite Trump’s Late Plea
item.media:description: On Wednesday, President Trump used Twitter to implore House Republicans to pass immigration legislation that would toughen border security. The vote failed 121 to 301.
item.description: Divided House Republicans failed to pass legislation to protect the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, fund a border wall and make significant changes to legal immigration.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS KAPLAN

item.title: California Banning Soda Taxes? A New Industry Strategy Is Stunning Some Lawmakers
item.media:description: “The soda industry has gone completely rogue,” said Scott Wiener, a state senator.
item.description: The bill to pre-empt taxes is part of a wider industry effort to skip cities and go straight to the states.
item.dc:creator: ANAHAD O’CONNOR and MARGOT SANGER-KATZ

item.title: China Extends Lead as Most Prolific Supercomputer Maker
item.media:description: The Sunway TaihuLight supercomputer when it was introduced in Wuxi, China, last December. At the time, it was the fastest computer in the world.
item.description: China’s corporations and its government made 206 of the world’s 500 fastest machines, moving further ahead of the number made in the United States.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR

item.title: How to Clean Your Filthy, Disgusting Laptop
item.description: Like any tool we use every day, our laptops accumulate dust, grime, oils from our skin and who knows what else. Yours is probably due for a cleaning, and here’s how to do it right.
item.dc:creator: WHITSON GORDON

item.title: Ever Felt Jealous of a Friend’s Achievement? Here’s How to Get Around It
item.media:description: High school students work on a four-hour philosophy dissertation for the general baccalaureat exam for university entry in Strasbourg, France, this month.
item.description: The eternal war between pride and jealousy.
item.dc:creator: TIM HERRERA

item.title: Getting to the Bottom of ‘Thrift Store Smell’
item.description: Have you noticed that every thrift store and neighborhood Goodwill smells the same? And that the clothes also smell the same? With the help of science, we got to the root of why. (And we have tips to help you get rid of it.)
item.dc:creator: JOLIE KERR

item.title: How to Plan the Perfect Trip With Your Significant Other This Summer
item.description: Make sure your bae-cation is one to remember — without the logistical headaches.
item.dc:creator: ANNA GOLDFARB

item.title: Joe Jackson, Domineering Father of a Musical Dynasty, Dies at 89
item.media:description: Joseph Jackson, father and manager of The Jackson Five, next to an Epic double platinum award, circa 1982.
item.description: His son Michael called him “a managerial genius,” but his abusive behavior alienated Michael, Janet and the rest of his children.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL E. SLOTNIK

item.title: The Secret Life of Sven
item.description: How a onetime acrobat and a “Lion King” puppet designer brought a speechless reindeer to life in Disney’s stage adaptation of “Frozen” on Broadway.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON and KARSTEN MORAN

item.title: Talk: Why Richard Painter Felt the Need to Switch Parties
item.media:description: Richard Painter
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.description: The ethics lawyer on Watergate, whether Al Franken was treated fairly and the most unethical person in the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Interview by DAN AMIRA

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Sleights of Hand With Cards, Coins and a Colander
item.media:description: Joshua Jay in “Six Impossible Things.”
item.description: The magicians Joshua Jay and Vitaly Beckman, both in one-man shows in Manhattan, are exploring uses of enchantment. And kitchen supplies.
item.dc:creator: ALEXIS SOLOSKI

item.title: Staying in the (Fashion) Moment
item.media:description: At the Rick Owens spring 2019 men's wear show in Paris.
item.media:credit: Valerio Mezzanotti for The New York Times
item.description: The monthlong men’s wear season, with stops in Florence, Milan and Paris, may not be hanging together thematically. But in terms of moments, it has provided some doozies.
item.dc:creator: GUY TREBAY

item.title: State of the Art: We Have Reached Peak Screen. Now Revolution Is in the Air.
item.description: With smartphones, everything digital has been managed through screens. Now that all of our visual capacity has been captured, the tech giants are starting to build a less eyes-only world.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Global Health: As an H.I.V. Prevention Drug Surged in Australia, Condom Use Fell
item.media:description: Increasing use of Truvada was linked to declining rates of H.I.V. infection, researchers found, but also to decreased use of condoms.
item.media:credit: Thor Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Infection rates declined despite a rise in unprotected sex, suggesting widespread use of the drug may mitigate the effects of riskier behavior.
item.dc:creator: EMILY BAUMGAERTNER

item.title: Nonfiction: Must Science Conflict With Spirituality?
item.description: The astrophysicist and novelist Alan Lightman doesn’t think so. And his new book, “Searching for Stars on an Island in Maine,” explains why.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SHERMER
item.category: Searching for Stars on an Island in Maine (Book)

item.title: ScienceTake: How Spiders Fly
item.description: Gossamer strands of spider silk serve as balloons to carry spiders far afield.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN
